text: Fade out music. Silence. A well-dressed black BOY and his MOTHER walk through seve galleries. They stand before Picasso's "Guernica," holding hands. The mother is disturbed. Crying. The boy looks up, confused and frightened, concerned to s mother crying in public. She looks at him tenderly. Her brow furrows. She stops crying. She stares just above eyes. Something's happening: she looks with wonder at the top o head... his eyes roll upward, trying to see - it's a crow He raises his hands. He touches it. A beam of light illuminates the crown, casting its glow o mother's face. The beam gets whiter, the rest of the screen gets black.
Silence. In darkness, we hear a VOICE - imbued with a sen its own history:

Everybody wants to get on the Van Gogh boat. There's no trip so horrible that someone won't take it. The idea of the unrecognized genius slaving away in a garret is a deliciously foolish one. We must credit the life of Vincent Van Gogh for really sending this myth into orbit. How many pictures did he sell? One? He couldn't give them away. We are so ashamed of his life that the rest of art history will be retribution for Van Gogh's neglect. No one wants to be part of a generation that ignores another Van Gogh. The beam of light shines through a small hole. It falls u sleeping, dreaming, delighted face. It belongs to JEAN MI BASQUIAT. OUTDOOR, DAYTIME SOUNDS filter in. Hearing the voice, Jean frowns at being woken up.
A long, rectangular cardboard box.
RENE RICARD (early 30's), seated at a park bench, hunched notebook. He's a raggedy dandy: A poet in a hooded sweats white hightops. As he writes, he reads aloud, as if addressing Posterity.
(sighing theatrically)
In this town one is at the mercy of the recognition factor. One's public appearance is absolute. Beyond him, a HAND gropes its way out of the box. It toss of YOOHOO chocolate drink. RENE (CONT'D)

I consider myself a metaphor of the public. I am a public eye. I am a witness. A HEAD appears from the box. It's Jean's. Jean sees the start of a crisp, colorful autumn day. The park around him is alive with a typically full range of t and bad in life. He eases himself out of the oversize box which he has spent the night. There's something about the that he stands while waking up that suggests he's almost surprised at his own body, the adultness of his limbs - j subtle hint of him coming out of a dream. He squints in the sunlight. He has a soft, gentle, Haitia His hair is pulled tight to his head. He wears two pairs jeans (one cut like chaps over the other) a paint-covered Wesleyan University T-shirt, and the inside lining of an overcoat. His appearance is unruly, but it's deliberate. stylish. He shakes himself off and collects his stuff, which inclu small book of Pontormo drawings, a can of black spray pai a cigar box made into a loudspeaker with pencil holes and tape. Jean walks out of the park and looks up past the building sky:
Jean sees the surfer, 'riding the nose' in glistening, sh sunlight.
Rene grabs the box for use as a desk and continues to spe loud as he writes. RENE (CONT'D, O.S.)
Part of the artist's job is to get the work where I will see it.
As he speaks, we see Jean pass the wall of a funeral parl spraypaints: "SAMO AS AN ALTERNATIVE TO GOD"

When you first see a new picture, you don't want to miss the boat. You have to be very careful because you may be staring at Van Gogh's ear. Jean signs his words with his 'logo', a triple pointed cr As he presses the spray can, we HEAR the roar of a breake
Pressed into the concrete is a pair of EYEGLASSES. A ligh colored piece of rock completes the picture to make a fac
JEAN'S POV: His shoes pause next to the face in the concr
Is a METAL BILLBOARD with red plastic magnetized LETTERS reads: "TODAY'S SPECIAL: CLAM CHOWDER $1.50. TRY IT!!!"
Jean enters.
The sign. It now reads: "SAMO'S DAY OLD TEETH $5.00"

Bending over a countertop, we see GINA CARDINALE, 22. He on her. She looks up and notices his stare. She continues to work Still staring at her, he sits down at a table. He pours m syrup onto the table. He draws in the syrup with his fing
ANOTHER WAITRESS arrives at his table. She's put off by t syrup. WAITRESS
What'll it be? Jean thinks about it, eyes still following Gina. BASQUIAT
Ummm. It'll be great. We'll live together in peace. What's her name? (indicates Gina)
He looks up at the waitress. WAITRESS
Gina. What'll it be? BASQUIAT

Pancakes. She leaves and whispers something to Gina. Gina turns and over at Jean. Jean pours more syrup and starts writing his name. At the grill, LESHKO, the burly Owner/Cook, has his watch on Jean. He doesn't like what he sees. Jean smears the syrup thinly, so it doesn't erase itself. draws a picture of Gina, using his fingers and the silver rendering her last expression strikingly with a few quick A GAUNT YOUNG MAN saunters up to Jean's table. He's sort tall Puerto Rican Alain Delon with sleepy eyes. He is BEN BENNY
Hey - Willie Mays. BASQUIAT
Willie Mays. Suddenly, Rene Ricard enters - a one-man parade. He becko Gina, snapping his fingers. RENE
Nurse!!! Oh!!! Nurse!!! Carrot juice. Tofu burger. Rapido! GINA
We don't serve that - amigo. RENE
Fine... A greasy cheeseburger. Fries - and a vodka. BASQUIAT (under his breath)
Who's that? BENNY
The Devil, man. Rene Ricard. Art critic - writes for Artforum. People read him. Tell him who you are..
Who am I?
Oh yeah.. Rene lands at the counter. Jean's gaze is still on Gina. She waits on a MAN at a nearby table. CUSTOMER
How's the special today? GINA
It's your stomach. She hurries past Jean.
Hey. She slows down, not wanting to. BASQUIAT (CONT'D)
What do you think? She looks at her portrait in the syrup... She can't resis smiling. GINA
It's me. I've never been done in maple syrup. Here's a rag. Gina smiles. She offers him one. As she holds it out, the lock. She tries to resist his smile.
(gently)
Gina? She puts her finger in the syrup and licks it off. Benny takes it all in. Leshko is upon them. LESHKO
Alright. Look at you, staring at this girl, making a mess. He waves Jean toward the door. Jean takes Gina's rag and begins cleaning his mess, seemi compliant. BASQUIAT
How about those pancakes? He brings out a roll of dimes to the tabletop and splits Dimes roll all over the table and stick in the syrupy par manager explodes. LESHKO
OK! Goodbye! GINA
Pipe down, Lech. Let him order. LESHKO
You nuts? Let him order? You on his side? You're not such a good waitress. You get out, too. GINA
I just don't think you're being fair. LESHKO
I need this? GINA
I need this? Gina quietly removes her apron in disbelief. Benny gets up to leave very casually. BENNY (waving g'bye to Jean)
Willie Mays. LESHKO (to Gina)
That's right. You go with them. Make babies the government has to pay for.
Leave the restaurant. Behind them, we see Rene, absorbed in his writing.
They stand outside, not knowing quite what comes next. Jean gives Benny a look (i.e. 'scram'). BENNY
Catch you later. Benny leaves. A CHILLY WIND picks up. Jean's mood is suddenly downcast. They button up their overcoats, about to leave. GINA
What's a job, anyway? (pause)
What's wrong with you? The truth is, he feels awful for causing Gina's trouble, shows it by moping like a child. GINA (CONT'D)
No, don't tell me - you just got fired by your crazy boss. BASQUIAT
I guess you did. GINA
Guess I just got sick of him. BASQUIAT
Can I walk you home? GINA
I think I could do that alone. Gina walks away. He runs after her. BASQUIAT
Wait, I'm in a band....We're at the Mudd Club on Halloween. I'll put you on the list. Gina turns and looks back at Jean. GINA
I hate the Mudd Club. He catches up to her. Gina notices a dead leaf in his hair and picks it out. GINA (CONT'D)
Have you been camping? You could use a scrub. BASQUIAT
I'm clean. Smell me. I always smell good. I don't know why, I just do! He leans forward, offering his neck. GINA (smelling)
You do! You definitely do. BASQUIAT
Just come to the Mudd Club on Friday. GINA
I don't go there. Too many party girls. BASQUIAT
Party girls? Can I call you? GINA (teasing him)
Yeah, if you have any dimes left. 477-0496. He writes her number on his pant cuff with a big fat magi marker. BASQUIAT
Here, this is for you. I made this. He hands her the small speaker. She takes it.
Thanks. She admires the speaker watches him walk off.
We see Jean crossing a lawn outside a mental hospital.

PSYCH. PATIENTS fill a cavernous day-room engaged in arts crafts. Some of the sadder patients stare off into space crosses the room. He carries a plate of cookies and a ful of milk. He approaches a sad, nice-looking, middle-aged black woma same one from the dream, earlier. She sits alone fondling pillow in her lap. It's his mother, MATILDE. She doesn't coming. As he sets the plate in front of her, she notices him. Sh recognizes him and seems pleased, even in her isolation. kisses her on the cheek. BASQUIAT

Hey, mom. She smiles slightly. Jean takes a cookie. She does likewise. They eat in silence, looking at each other, communicating they can. Time passes. In between cookies her fingers find and brea stems of the pillow feathers. BASQUIAT (CONT'D)
I met the girl I'm gonna marry. His mother brightens. She drinks the milk. They finish th cookies. MATILDE
Do you like it here? BASQUIAT
I'd like it better in Hawaii.
Jean tries to sleep in the box. RAIN falls heavily onto i Drops of water hit his face. He wills it to stop. It doesn't. Finally, he can't stand it. Rain forces his blinking eyes

A door opens to reveal Jean's wet face. Benny lets him in. Jean enters a rundown railroad flat crammed with musical instruments, beer cans, and homemade art. There's a couch sheet over it. Junk is piled in a corner - mostly art books and drawings Benny sits down at an electric piano, which he's evidentl playing. He sings along, softly, working out the words, concentrating, absorbed. Jean sets his belongings on the couch, walks to a mic sta starts making up his own words. BASQUIAT
"She loves me. Oh yeah she loves me! She loooooooves me, Oh yeah she loves me!" Bring me some chicken, baby! BENNY
Would you shut the fuck up? You hear what I'm doing? BASQUIAT
Yeah man. I'm jealous. You're always great, Benny. (goes back into 'act')

"Her name is G-I-N-A Gina And she lo-oooves me." I did say chicken! Benny turns off the piano and lights a roach, angry at Je self-centeredness. Jean digs through a pile of garbage. Finally, he finds wh looking for - a pile of "SAMO baseball cards" - color Xer his favorite images and words. He pockets them. BASQUIAT (CONT'D)
I knew I left these somewhere. One of these'll send your kids to college someday. (hands it to Benny solemnly)
Here - I made this for you. BENNY
Thanks. (beat)
Your dad called again - something about a job. He hands Jean a slip of paper. He notices the number on J pants. BENNY (CONT'D)
You got a date already? BASQUIAT (exhaling)

We're getting married. She said she could tell I was a great artist - she could see it in my eyes. She said she wanted to be by my side and have inter-racial babies with me. Benny grins. He grabs a basketball and spins it expertly index finger. BENNY

G'night... See you in court tomorrow. Jean turns on the TV. He notices the roach. He picks up t Benny gave him with the message from his father and sets fire. He lights the roach with it. He looks up; on television, we see a BUM being interviewe turns up the volume. The bum's on the ground, looking beat up. Jean picks up a recorder and turns it on: BUM

The guy just hit me and I was on the ground!!!! Boom, for real. Jean mutes the sound on the TV. He rewinds and proudly pl the words "Boom, for real." He picks up the phone and dials. He turns on the speakerp Jean holds the recorder to the speaker as someone answers phone. (Jean walks in and out of frame throughout the fol VOICE
Hello? BASQUIAT (deadpan)
I-Is this the s-s-suicide h-h-hotline? VOICE
Yes. My name is Chris. What's yours? BASQUIAT
Jean Michel. CHRIS
That's a beautiful name. French? BASQUIAT

Haitian. I'm going to kill myself. I'm taking pills. Reds, blues, greens. Jean opens his notepad and looks down a long list of seem random words. He comes to the words (in order) "liquid, h and "Marlboros." CHRIS
What? Wait a minute... talk to me. BASQUIAT (about to sob)
Life doesn't... make... sense. This city's k-killing me. I want my liquid hijack Marlboros! CHRIS
What? Life's beautiful. Depression isn't permanent. Don't you believe that? (pause)
What is it - did your girlfriend leave you? BASQUIAT
No! I have a boyfriend. He loves me. Jean spies an electric pencil sharpener and plugs it in. CHRIS
You see? You have someone to live for. BASQUIAT
No, I don't. I'm alone. We all are. Especially here. The world's unjust. The respect fools get. The disrespect I get. CHRIS

What is it you want?    Respect? I have respect for you, just    for making this call. One philosopher said    "Sadness is a sin against the richness    of the world." Think about it. Feel it. BASQUIAT
You don't even know me. I want real respect. He jams a pencil into the electric sharpener and holds th receiver right next to it, giving the guy an earful:
CLOSE UP - A speaker. It fills the screen. We continue to hear: CHRIS (O.S.) (beat)
What? What do you want? BASQUIAT (breaking loose)
Fame. My liquid hijack Marlboros and the moon and the cow that jumped over it.

head_text.subj: CAMERA PULLS BACK FROM SPEAKER TO REVEAL

text: Jean and Benny are on stage with two other GUYS, members band Gray. Everyone but Jean is dressed in some sort of H costume. We HEAR the words "Boom, for real" blasting from the P.A. What follows is a continuation, a collage of words from J "suicide hotline" call - P.A.

One philosopher said "Give me my liquid hijack Marlboros. Life's beautiful. You have someone to live for. What do you want? RKKKK! That's a beautiful name... French? Jean sits in a chair onstage with his band members. Benny the organ. The other band members play percussion and gui It works. The crowd loves it. The song ends abruptly. We begin to hear James Brown's "Sex Machine." Jean looks out into the crowd and notices Gina. She's loo right back at him from the bar. Pleased to see her face, to himself - BASQUIAT
Boom, for real. We see him walk offstage into the crowd. They meet. BASQUIAT (CONT'D)
I thought you hated this place?
I do. (beat)
I just said that. I was never here before. I actually like it. MUSIC segues into PIL's "Public Image". BASQUIAT
Let's get out of here. He leads her towards the exit. They step out of the club.

It's raining heavily. Jean motions for Gina to wait under entrance. He tries to hail a cab... And another. And anot A parade of them passes, but each time they slow down, th glimpse of Jean and drive off. Finally, Gina steps out of the entrance. She raises her h a car pulls over instantly.
They scurry into the backseat. The cab pulls off.
Through a steamy, rain-wet window, we see Jean and Gina s a table, dining. They seem to be having a nice time.
Gina lays in bed. Daylight streams into the apartment. Jackhammers RATTLE outside. (Music: REGGAE SONG - Errol Scorcher's "Cockroach in de Corner.")

A cockroach crawls from Gina's bedroom across the floor a the kitchen where Jean sits naked on the floor, working o drawing. It crawls over his drawing towards a cardboard b Jean rummages through a cabinet. He finds a can of bugspr tears off a side of the box. With cardboard in one hand a bugspray in the other, he forgets the cockroach. He's mesmerized by the list of ingredients on the aerosol Someone POUNDS furiously at the door. Ignoring the pounding, he starts listing the ingredients piece of cardboard, finishing his new drawing by includin symbol of a cockroach to the left of the list. LANDLADY
Miss Cardinale... Open up for me, please! He gets up and peeks through the security hole. He sees a aged Hispanic woman reaching to unlock the door. He opens LANDLADY (CONT'D)
Ohhh, Dios mio! She stares at him levelly. LANDLADY (CONT'D)
I just want the rent. BASQUIAT

Why didn't you say so? Damn! She's asleep! Jean draws on a piece of paper on the counter next to him hands it to the landlady. It's a a little shack with a bi next to it that says "'Here' For Rent." The landlady looks at him like he's crazy. She balls up t drawing and puts it in her pocket. Gina arrives in the doorway, wearing a robe. The landlady trapped between them. GINA (to Jean)
What're you doing? The landlady wags her finger at Gina. LANDLADY
Next Monday. Gina and Jean look amused as they watch her leave. BASQUIAT
Wanna go get some breakfast? GINA

A friend of mine offered me a job doing a little work installing a show in a gallery. He's an electrician. I was supposed to be there an hour ago. She looks at the bugspray drawing on the floor. GINA (CONT'D)
Ohh, that's nice. Jean kisses her neck as she looks at the drawing. We HOLD on the drawing.

White dust sprinkles down onto Jean's face from the ceili Unable to use his hands, he tries to blow the dust out of eyes... His boss, GREG, a mild-mannered hippie electrician, works him on the ladder. Jean steadies the ladder. Greg's head of frame. The gallery is an impressive space under preparations for opening. GREG
Jean, could you get me a Phillips screwdriver? BASQUIAT
A what? GREG
A Phillips head. From the toolbox. BASQUIAT
Yeah. Jean searches through the toolbox. He picks up a screwdri reads the handle: "CRAFTSMAN"
'Phillips head,' right?
Yeah. Jean shakes his head and puts it back. He tries a couple they each say "CRAFTSMAN." He puts them back. Finally, he finds one with a different handle. It says "G
You don't have any!!!
That's impossible. I've got, like, five of 'em! He comes down off the ladder.
You're holding one in your hand!!! (beat)
You've never done this kind of work before, have you? (demonstrating)

See, this is a regular screwdriver, and this is a Phillips head. The cross thing... I'll tell you later what all the tools are so you'll know. A GROUP of people arrives. Albert Milo    comes into view, tailed closely by Rene Ri MARY BOONE    - well dressed, petite, intense, 30. Milo, 30), wears    casual clothes splattered with paint. Mary engaged in    conversation with Milo. Rene chatters away. Greg climbs back up the ladder. He holds a piece of wire Jean. Jean stares at the group while trying to be invisib
I need to make a call, Mary. You don't mind, do you?
Certainly not. You can use my line. Rene picks up the phone.
To Paris. Bernard Picasso - (to Mary)
You know Bernard -
(wincing)
Be my guest. Jean watches the group talking. GREG
Jean? Hold this, please. (beat - he sees why Jean's so distracted)
You'll get there. But it's good to have something to fall back on. That's why I became an electrician. It pays the rent. Y'know, I'm an artist, too. BASQUIAT
I didn't know. GREG

I sculpt. I'm really just starting to find myself. How old are you? Twenty? You're just like I used to be. I'm forty-one. And I'm glad I haven't gotten any recognition. It gave me time to develop. Jean watches Mary and Milo talking. MARY BOONE (to Milo)
I can't tell you how happy I am with this show. Mary yells across the room to Jean. MARY BOONE (CONT'D) (her tone impersonal)
Excuse me - you - what's your name? Would you move those tools there and put them somewhere else? He looks at her. Milo watches to see what he's going to do. BASQUIAT (to Milo)
My name is Jean Michel Basquiat. Have you heard of me? ALBERT MILO (amused)
No. Should I have? BASQUIAT
I'm a painter, too. ALBERT MILO
Really. Huh. Too bad. MARY BOONE
Excuse me, would you please move those tools? Jean looks at Milo. Milo looks back at him. Jean walks past the tools and continues toward the door. out without turning around. Milo smiles to himself.

The ART WORLD CROWD fills the gallery. Jean lurks across street, watching through the window. Cabs and limousines line the block. A crowd outside block street. Jean's obviously impressed, jealous and estranged -     h entitled to all this. He crosses the street to get a closer look.

He sees Albert Milo    talking with ANDY WARHOL and BRUNO BISCHOFBERGER. Andy,    of course, is thin, silver-haired nearly albino. Bruno    is a Swiss art dealer in his 40's money - a pillar of    security. On the other side of the room, Rene Ricard is surrounded coterie of young, mostly BLACK AND HISPANIC MALES. Rene l drunk, enjoying the moment, holding court. Rene crosses to Albert and Andy. People pass by. Jean starts to walk. About half a block away, he sprays on a wall:

head_text.subj: "THE WHOLE LIVERY LINE BOW LIKE THIS WITH THE BIG MONEY A

text: He looks pleased. He turns and looks up West Broadway bey buildings at the sky:
We see a surfer emerging from a HUGE WAVE. He looks power exalted.
ANGLE ON: A wall. We see the following graffity:

head_text.subj: "JIMMY BEST ON HIS BACK TO THE SUCKERPUNCH OF HIS CHILDHO

text: A basketball bounces against a wall. Jean and Benny amble onto a basketball court. Jean's chan hairstyle. Now the dreadlocks stand straight up from his Benny dribbles with skill while Jean puffs furiously on a cigarette. He doesn't look like he's slept, but he's happ Benny throws the ball to Jean. It bounces off a puddle an splashes Jean. BENNY
Come on, Jean. Get rid of your cigarette. Concentrate. BASQUIAT
I am... On Gina. (beat)
Fuck - I didn't think we were actually gonna do this. BENNY
Concentrate on the ball. Shoot. Jean shoots. It flies up, up, up -     and over the backb He runs after the ball, gets it, and dribbles clumsily. BENNY
You're shattering all my myths.
About what? BENNY
Your people. BASQUIAT
Oh - you mean black people! He shoots and misses again. He throws it to Benny, who do picture-perfect lay-up. BASQUIAT (CONT'D) (changing the subject)
How long do you think it takes to get really famous? During the following, Benny performs a series of amazing while Jean looks on admiringly. BENNY
For a musician or a painter? Jean shrugs. BASQUIAT
Whatever. Famous. To where you can do your stuff all day without thinking about anything else. BENNY
Ummm... Four years. Six to get rich. He shoots. Swish. BENNY (CONT'D)
First, you have to dress right. He shoots again. Swish. BENNY (CONT'D)
Then, you have to hang out all the time - with famous people - the right people, the right chicks, the right parties. He shoots again. Swish. BENNY (CONT'D)

And you gotta do your work all the time when you're not doing that. The same kinda work, the same style - over and over again, so people recognize it and don't get confused. Then, once you're famous, you have to keep doing it the same way, even after it's boring - unless you want people to really get mad at you - which they will anyway. Benny tosses Jean the ball. Jean walks off the court. BASQUIAT
Come on. I hate this. I'm no good at it. Jean shoots the ball and keeps walking. The ball goes in. doesn't notice. Benny runs after it.
Benny and Jean walk along. Benny dribbles. BENNY

Famous people are usually pretty stupid. You're too smart. You'd get bored to death. You don't wanna be like John Henry - fighting the machine. Just do what you do. It's about integrity. Follow your heart. BASQUIAT
Who's John Henry? BENNY

Oh man! Folklore guy - worked on the railroad. Y'know, pounding in spikes and laying down track. Then one day they invented a machine to do it. And he says "Fuck that, I'm a MAN" and he challenges the machine to a race to lay down a mile of track. It takes two days. Neck and neck the whole time. They get right to the end, and he beats it by one spike. (pause)
Got a cigarette? BASQUIAT
So then what? BENNY

He drops dead! See? Just do your shit like you do it! Your friends like you, you get laid, everyone walks by, sees your stuff everywhere. It's good. What else do you want? They watch a long stretch limo cruises up across the stre BASQUIAT
Like I said - my liquid hijack Marlboros. (indicates limo)
Check it out. The LIMO DRIVER opens the back door. Andy Warhol and Brun Bischofberger step out. BASQUIAT (CONT'D)
Andy Warhol. He's famous and he's not boring.
(FOOTAGE FROM JONAS MEKAS FILM)
Jean scrounges in his pockets, pulls out his Xerox cards, readies himself as Bruno and Andy enter BALLATO'S RESTAUR BENNY
What're you doing? You're doing something. BASQUIAT
He's the best painter in the world. I'm gonna give him one of these. BENNY

Don't give him anything, man. Your art's worth a lot. Trade. That's what real artists do with each other. Besides, he'll just use you. He's famous for that. Benny watches Jean crosses the street. Jean passes the li Inside, the driver (a 24-year old Rasta) takes a hit from and watches Jean.
The driver's eyes.
He watches Jean cross the street. Jean enters the restaurant.
Jean enters. Andy and Bruno spot him. The Maitre'd become alarmed. but it's too late - he's at their table. He spreads his cards on the table. The topmost card reads
Andy stares dead ahead, Sphinxlike. Bruno watches the non-interaction between the two. MAITRE'D (to Jean, flustered)
Can I help you?. He taps Jean's shoulder. MAITRE'D (CONT'D) (to Jean)
Sir...? BRUNO (sympathetically)
I think it's ok. MAITRE'D
Of course, Mr. Bischofberger. Bruno picks up one of the cards. BASQUIAT
You wanna buy some ignorant art? Ten bucks. ANDY WARHOL
Ignorant art? BASQUIAT
Yeah... Like - stupid, ridiculous, crummy art. ANDY WARHOL
Ohhh. That's new. That sounds good. BASQUIAT
Ten bucks apiece. ANDY WARHOL
I can give you five. You didn't do very much to these. BASQUIAT
You don't even work on your stuff! BRUNO
It doesn't matter how much you worked on them. It matters how much you can get for them. BASQUIAT
I can get ten. ANDY WARHOL
I'll take two. This one and... that one. (to Bruno)
Can I borrow some money, Bruno? Bruno pulls out a hundred dollar bill. BRUNO
Here. Do you have change? As WAITER arrives with the tray, Jean pockets the bill. BASQUIAT
You made a good deal. Here, you can have these, too. He leaves all the cards and walks toward the door.
Jean leaving past stupified Maitre'd.
Jean and Benny are outside the entrance to Gina's buildin carries two huge bags overflowing with groceries and flow buzzes. There's no answer. BASQUIAT
I'll be right back. He produces a key and lets himself in. He enters the building.
Jean sets the groceries on the counter and leaves. We notice the Bugspray painting on the wall, along with m Jean's work and supplies.
Jean rejoins Benny in front of Gina's building. As they're leaving, Gina comes up the street. BASQUIAT (to Benny)
Check you later, man. BENNY
Hi Gina. GINA
Hi.
Flowers and groceries are strewn on the counter.
Over the following MONTAGE we HEAR: RENE (O.S.)

... 'APT 20'... The church bells would ring at noon and six a.m.. 24 strokes: How many times we counted them. We called our bed the cloud. And there we'd float. The bathtub was in the kitchen and took forever to fill up. We'd bathe together afterwards. Oh the countless cigarettes and take out Chinese food... The bed was so narrow Three years we made it fit. The sheets were green the sheets were pink the sheets white linen from the past. Little home, farewell, The broken windows and the bodega on the corner. Now from my balcony I look out over all New York...
Jean and Gina are sleeping. SERIES OF DISSOLVES: As they're turning together in their
Filled with Jean's paintings. SERIES OF DISSOLVES: Paintings and objects fill the room.

Jean watches "The Little Rascals" on TV in the living roo sound is turned off and a record player PLAYS Gypsy music Rolled up in a large drop cloth, Gina is asleep on the fl Next to her, Jean works on all fours, drawing figures, cr and houses. Working feverishly, he writes "HEY, HEY, HEY" in big clus then writes other words: SHARK, IMMORTALITY, JOHN THE REV FAME, INK, TEETH, HAWAII SUPERMARKET, POLE STAR, BABOON a He has an acoustics manual and Bible open    on the floor the technical blueprints from the manual.    He reads the following the text with a dirty finger. It    seems that TV, draws, listens to the music and reads    at the same He mixes Liquitex paints and puts some colors on the draw draws a long blue line and carries it over onto the floor wall. This is painted on a backdrop from the Kabuki theater in Japan. I painted it after Joseph Beuys died. A rebirth painting. BASQUIAT

There was this little prince with a magic crown. An evil warlock kidnapped him, locked him in a cell in a huge tower and took away his voice. There was a window made of bars. The prince would smash his head against the bars hoping that someone would hear the sound and find him. The crown made the most beautiful sound that anyone ever heard. You could hear the ringing for miles. It was so beautiful, that people wanted to grab the air. They never found the prince. He never got out of the room. But the sound he made filled everything up with beauty. BASQUIAT (O.S)
